Fundamental Limitations on Subquadratic Alternatives to Transformers

Josh Alman Department of Computer Science, Columbia University, NY 10027. Email: josh@cs.columbia.edu. â€ƒâ€ƒ Hantao Yu Department of Computer Science, Columbia University, NY 10027. Email: hantao.yu@columbia.edu.
Abstract

The Transformer architecture is widely deployed in many popular and impactful Large Language Models. At its core is the attention mechanism for calculating correlations between pairs of tokens. Performing an attention computation takes quadratic time in the input size, and had become the time bottleneck for transformer operations. In order to circumvent this, researchers have used a variety of approaches, including designing heuristic algorithms for performing attention computations faster, and proposing alternatives to the attention mechanism which can be computed more quickly. For instance, state space models such as Mamba were designed to replace attention with an almost linear time alternative.

In this paper, we prove that any such approach cannot perform important tasks that Transformer is able to perform (assuming a popular conjecture from fine-grained complexity theory). We focus on document similarity tasks, where one is given as input many documents and would like to find a pair which is (approximately) the most similar. We prove that Transformer is able to perform this task, and we prove that this task cannot be performed in truly subquadratic time by any algorithm. Thus, any model which can be evaluated in subquadratic time â€“ whether because of subquadratic-time heuristics for attention, faster attention replacements like Mamba, or any other reason â€“ cannot perform this task. In other words, in order to perform tasks that (implicitly or explicitly) involve document similarity, one may as well use Transformer and cannot avoid its quadratic running time.

1 Introduction

The Transformer architecture [71] is widely used for natural language processing [27, 77], computer vision [26, 23], and many other tasks, and has achieved state-of-the-art performance for numerous applications. At the core of the architecture is the attention mechanism which is designed to calculate the correlation between all pairs of tokens in a given input sequence. Namely, let Qâˆˆâ„dinÃ—mğ‘„superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘inğ‘šQ\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\textup{in}}\times m}italic_Q âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the query matrix, Kâˆˆâ„dinÃ—mğ¾superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘inğ‘šK\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\textup{in}}\times m}italic_K âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the key matrix and Vâˆˆâ„dinÃ—doutğ‘‰superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘insubscriptğ‘‘outV\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\textup{in}}\times d_{\textup{out}}}italic_V âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT out end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the value matrix. Given Xâˆˆâ„nÃ—dinğ‘‹superscriptâ„ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘inX\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d_{\textup{in}}}italic_X âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, an attention mechanism computes

AQ,K,Vâ¢(X):=softmaxâ¢(Xâ¢Qâ¢KâŠ¤â¢XâŠ¤)â¢Xâ¢Vassignsubscriptğ´ğ‘„ğ¾ğ‘‰ğ‘‹softmaxğ‘‹ğ‘„superscriptğ¾topsuperscriptğ‘‹topğ‘‹ğ‘‰A_{Q,K,V}(X):=\textup{softmax}(XQK^{\top}X^{\top})XVitalic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q , italic_K , italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) := softmax ( italic_X italic_Q italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_X italic_V

where the softmax operator

softmaxâ¢(v)=(expâ¡(vâ¢[1]),â€¦,expâ¡(vâ¢[n]))âˆ‘i=1nexpâ¡(vâ¢[i])softmaxğ‘£ğ‘£delimited-[]1â€¦ğ‘£delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘£delimited-[]ğ‘–\textup{softmax}(v)=\frac{(\exp(v[1]),\ldots,\exp(v[n]))}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\exp(v% [i])}softmax ( italic_v ) = divide start_ARG ( roman_exp ( italic_v [ 1 ] ) , â€¦ , roman_exp ( italic_v [ italic_n ] ) ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp ( italic_v [ italic_i ] ) end_ARG

for vâˆˆâ„nğ‘£superscriptâ„ğ‘›v\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_v âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is applied to matrices row-wise. Computing the attention by straightforwardly following the definition above requires quadratic time (in the sequence length nğ‘›nitalic_n), which prohibits efficient model training when the sequence length is too large. As a result, much effort has been devoted to overcoming this obstacle in recent years, and there are two major lines of research to tackle the problem.

The first line of research argues that instead of computing attention exactly in the worst case, it often suffices to use heuristics which work well when the input data has additional structure, or to only return coarse approximations of the attention mechanism which can be computed more quickly. Examples including KDEformer [79], Reformer [45], Hyperattention [37], Linformer [75], SMYRF [29], and Performer [22]. In many cases, these heuristics result in algorithms which run in close to linear time. However, these techniques usually have corresponding downsides, such as model accuracy drops, or performance gains which do not appear to scale to large inputs.

The second line of research argues that instead of computing or approximating attention, we can replace the standard attention mechanism with new, different mechanisms which can be computed faster. Models such as Longformer [19], Synthesizer [67], Routing transformers [59], and Mamba [33] all aim to circumvent the quadratic barrier by proposing new attention alternatives. A priori, these techniques would result in weaker expressiveness since they replace attentionâ€™s calculation of token interactions with simpler alternatives, although most also provide empirical evidence that the loss in accuracy at certain tasks is not large.

In this paper, we prove that any approach that takes subquadratic time, no matter whether it uses heuristic or approximations, or a new architecture, or a completely different approach, is inherently unable to perform important learning tasks that a transformer is able to perform. By using tools and popular hardness conjectures from the area of fine-grained complexity theory, we show that many learning tasks involving document similarity cannot possibly be solved in subquadratic time using any algorithmic approach. This implies that subquadratic alternatives to standard transformers are not able to solve these simple and natural tasks in machine learning and NLP. To complement this, we show that standard transformers (even simple transformers with one layer and one attention head) are able to perform these tasks, thereby establishing a separation between standard transformers and these new approaches. In other words, we prove that accuracy loss for any task relating to document similarity is unavoidable for any subquadratic approach, even when compared only to the simplest transformers, because of the inherent computational complexity of the task.

1.1 Document Similarity

In this work we will be focusing on document similarity tasks. We will show that standard transformers are capable of solving these tasks but subquadratic alternatives to transformers cannot.

Document similarity is a fundamental area in natural language processing with many applications including recommender systems [57], search engines [51], and plagiarism-detection [18]. For a given document Dğ·Ditalic_D, we first need to define a document embedding to transform it into a vector vâˆˆâ„dğ‘£superscriptâ„ğ‘‘v\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_v âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and we will then measure how similar two documents are by using a similarity measure on their embedding vectors. There are many ways to embed a document as a vector including Doc2Vec [50], TF-IDF [65], BERT [27], bag-of-words [36], and many ways to measure how similar two documents are including cosine similarity, Euclidean distance, and Jaccard Similarity. In this work, we focus on two of the most popular options, bag-of-words embedding and cosine similarity, although our results extend naturally to almost any reasonable alternatives.

Bag-of-words Embedding.

Bag-of-words embedding is a well-studied method of embedding [17] that is commonly used for text classification [44], radiology [43] and many other settings, especially in NLP. Given a document Dğ·Ditalic_D and a list of â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ key words, the bag-of-words embedding of Dğ·Ditalic_D is a vector vâˆˆ{0,1}â„“ğ‘£superscript01â„“v\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_v âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th entry of vğ‘£vitalic_v corresponds to whether the iğ‘–iitalic_i-th key word exists in Dğ·Ditalic_D or not. 111Sometimes the entries are also frequency counts, but that would only make the embedding vectors more complex. Since our main goal is to show hardness, we will focus on the simpler binary case. For example, if a document only contains one sentence â€œThere are ten apples on the apple treeâ€ and the key words chosen are â€œappleâ€, â€œtreeâ€, â€œcomputerâ€ and â€œtenâ€, this document will have bag-of-words embedding (1,1,0,1)1101(1,1,0,1)( 1 , 1 , 0 , 1 ).

Cosine Similarity.

Cosine similarity is one of the most commonly used method to measure how similar two documents are. Given two document embeddings v,wâˆˆâ„dğ‘£ğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘v,w\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_v , italic_w âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the cosine similarity is given by

âŸ¨v,wâŸ©â€–vâ€–2â‹…â€–wâ€–2âˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘£ğ‘¤â‹…subscriptnormğ‘£2subscriptnormğ‘¤201\frac{\langle v,w\rangle}{\|v\|_{2}\cdot\|w\|_{2}}\in[0,1]divide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_v , italic_w âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_v âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‹… âˆ¥ italic_w âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ]

where 1111 represents complete similarity and 00 represents no similarity. It is defined in this way, rather than just taking the inner product âŸ¨v,wâŸ©ğ‘£ğ‘¤\langle v,w\rangleâŸ¨ italic_v , italic_w âŸ©, so that two documents (vectors) with large magnitude can still be considered close if they have similar directions. Cosine similarity is one of the most popular and effective measures; for instance, [62] found that when used for extractive multi-document text summarization, cosine similarity gives the best results.

Problem Statement.

We define our most similar document (ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£)ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£(\mathsf{MSD})( sansserif_MSD ) and least similar document (ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£)ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£(\mathsf{LSD})( sansserif_LSD ) problems as: given a set of nğ‘›nitalic_n binary vectors v1,â€¦,vnsubscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of length dğ‘‘ditalic_d (document embeddings), the goal is to find two documents that are the most/least similar to each other in terms of cosine similarity. There are many natural variants of these two problems, and we prove similar hardness for all of them:

  1. 1.

    (Bichromatic ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£,ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD},\mathsf{LSD}sansserif_MSD , sansserif_LSD) Sometimes we have two sets of documents A,Bğ´ğµA,Bitalic_A , italic_B and we want to find one document from each set such that the pair is (un)similar.

  2. 2.

    (Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£,Î³â¢-â¢ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ›¾-ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ›¾-ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£\gamma\textup{-}\mathsf{MSD},\gamma\textup{-}\mathsf{LSD}italic_Î³ - sansserif_MSD , italic_Î³ - sansserif_LSD) Sometimes we might only need to find a pair of documents that is approximately the most (un)similar, (up to an approximation factor Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³) and not necessarily the optimal pair.

  3. 3.

    (ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,d,t,ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,d,t)subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘¡(\mathsf{MSD}_{n,d,t},\mathsf{LSD}_{n,d,t})( sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_d , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_d , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) Sometimes we only want to know if there exists a pair whose cosine similarity is above (or below) a threshold tâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¡01t\in[0,1]italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ].

These variants occur in many practical scenarios when using a large language model. They can arise explicitly when the descriptions of nğ‘›nitalic_n documents of size â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ are given to a language model, and the model is asked to find the most similar pair of documents. However, there are many scenarios where document similarity can arise implicitly as well. For example,

  • â€¢

    when an animal protection organization has the profiles of nğ‘›nitalic_n pets and nğ‘›nitalic_n families and wants to find a best match for adoption;

  • â€¢

    when a college professor wants to see if there is any academic integrity issues in an important exam;

  • â€¢

    when one wants to find repetitive or redundant passages in a text, and thus must implicitly determine which pair of passages is most similar.

1.2 Main Results

Our hardness results are based on a prevalent conjecture from fine-grained complexity theory called the Strong Exponential Time Hypothesis (ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§)ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§(\mathsf{SETH})( sansserif_SETH ):

for every Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0, there is an integer kğ‘˜kitalic_k such that kâ¢ğ–²ğ– ğ–³ğ‘˜ğ–²ğ– ğ–³k\mathsf{SAT}italic_k sansserif_SAT with nğ‘›nitalic_n variables requires Î©â¢(2(1âˆ’Îµ)â¢n)Î©superscript21ğœ€ğ‘›\Omega(2^{(1-\varepsilon)n})roman_Î© ( 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time.

ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH was first introduced by [41], and is a popular strengthening of the conjecture that ğ–¯â‰ ğ–­ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ–­ğ–¯\mathsf{P}\neq\mathsf{NP}sansserif_P â‰  sansserif_NP. (In other words, proving that ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH is true implies ğ–¯â‰ ğ–­ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ–­ğ–¯\mathsf{P}\neq\mathsf{NP}sansserif_P â‰  sansserif_NP.) Since then, there has been a long line of work studying and making use of ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH. Prior work has given theoretical evidence for ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH, including showing that if ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH is false, then surprising complexity-theoretic consequences would follow [41, 1, 70], and using ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH to prove hardness of problems in many different areas of algorithm design. See the survey [74] for a detailed background.

Main Results: Limitations of subquadratic alternatives.

We show that ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£,ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD},\mathsf{LSD}sansserif_MSD , sansserif_LSD and their variants require quadratic time assuming ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH for some natural choice of parameters, and therefore any subquadratic alternatives to transformers are not able to solve them due to computational constraints. The formal hardness results are as follows, and vary slightly in the dimension parameter â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ depending on the details of the problem:

Theorem 1.1 (TheoremÂ 3.1 and Corollary 3.2).

Assuming ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH, for every Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0, there exists a constant c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0 such that ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“subscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell}sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot be solved in Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time when â„“=câ¢logâ¡nâ„“ğ‘ğ‘›\ell=c\log nroman_â„“ = italic_c roman_log italic_n. Moreover, the same lower bound also holds for ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“,tsubscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for some 0<t<10ğ‘¡10<t<10 < italic_t < 1, Î³â¢-â¢ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“ğ›¾-subscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any Î³â‰¥1ğ›¾1\gamma\geq 1italic_Î³ â‰¥ 1, and bichromatic ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“subscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell}sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Theorem 1.2 (TheoremÂ 3.3 and Corollary 3.4).

Assuming ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH, for every Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0, there exists a constant c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0 such that ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot be solved in Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time when â„“=nclogâ¡logâ¡nâ„“superscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘›\ell=n^{\frac{c}{\log\log n}}roman_â„“ = italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_c end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Moreover, the same lower bound also holds for ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“,tsubscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for some 0<t<10ğ‘¡10<t<10 < italic_t < 1 and Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“ğ›¾-subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any 1â‰¤Î³â‰¤polylogâ¡(n)1ğ›¾polylogğ‘›1\leq\gamma\leq\operatorname{polylog}(n)1 â‰¤ italic_Î³ â‰¤ roman_polylog ( italic_n ).

For bichromatic ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD}sansserif_MSD we can obtain a stronger hardness result.

Theorem 1.3 (TheoremÂ 3.3 and Corollary 3.4).

Assuming ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH, for every Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0, there exists a constant c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0 such that bichromatic ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot be solved in Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time when â„“=câ¢logâ¡nâ„“ğ‘ğ‘›\ell=c\log nroman_â„“ = italic_c roman_log italic_n.

In all these problems, we prove hardness when â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ is Î˜â¢(logâ¡n)Î˜ğ‘›\Theta(\log n)roman_Î˜ ( roman_log italic_n ) or noâ¢(1)superscriptğ‘›ğ‘œ1n^{o(1)}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This is a natural choice: for any smaller â„“<logâ¡nâ„“ğ‘›\ell<\log nroman_â„“ < roman_log italic_n, there could be at most 2â„“<nsuperscript2â„“ğ‘›2^{\ell}<n2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < italic_n vectors under a bag-of-words embedding, which means that there would be duplicate vectors in our instance. Making â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ larger can only make the problem harder.

It follows that any language task which, either explicitly or implicitly, involves solving any of these document similarity problems, cannot be solved in subquadratic time, no matter what the parameters or architecture of the language model are.222We briefly emphasize that the parameter â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ in these similarity problems need not be related to the architecture or parameters (like din,doutsubscriptğ‘‘insubscriptğ‘‘outd_{\textup{in}},d_{\textup{out}}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT out end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, etc) of a language model which solves the problems. For instance, to ask a language model to solve ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we may ask it â€œWhich of the following paragraphs is most similar?â€ followed by a list of nğ‘›nitalic_n different paragraphs of at most â„“â„“\ellroman_â„“ words each. Thus, the input to the language model would be a string of length Oâ¢(nâ¢â„“)ğ‘‚ğ‘›â„“O(n\ell)italic_O ( italic_n roman_â„“ ), and since â„“<noâ¢(1)â„“superscriptğ‘›ğ‘œ1\ell<n^{o(1)}roman_â„“ < italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is small compared to nğ‘›nitalic_n, our result shows that a language model would need to take quadratic time in the string length to answer this type of query.

Main Results: Representational strength of standard transformers.

When a problem requires quadratic time to solve, this means that subquadratic-time models cannot solve it, but it does not necessarily mean that a transformer model can solve it. For example, [63] defined a problem called â€œMatch3â€ which can be solved in quadratic time by a textbook algorithm, but which they prove cannot be solved by a one-layer transformer unless it has a lot of attention heads or a very high embedding dimension.

We show that this is not the case for ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD}sansserif_MSD and ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{LSD}sansserif_LSD by showing that a single standard attention unit with input and output MLPs can solve ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,d,t,ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,d,tsubscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘¡\mathsf{MSD}_{n,d,t},\mathsf{LSD}_{n,d,t}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_d , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_d , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ–®ğ–µğ–®ğ–µ\mathsf{OV}sansserif_OV. Thus, these problems establish a separation between standard transformers and subquadratic alternatives to transformers.

Theorem 1.4 (TheoremsÂ 4.1 andÂ 4.3).

A single unit of standard attention with input and output MLPs, embedding dimension â„“+1â„“1\ell+1roman_â„“ + 1 can solve ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“,t,ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“,tsubscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡subscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell,t},\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any 0â‰¤tâ‰¤10ğ‘¡10\leq t\leq 10 â‰¤ italic_t â‰¤ 1.

In principle, there could be concerns with representational results like these that the weights of the model are complicated and hard to find in training. However, our constructions of transformers that solve these problems are very simple: our MLPs are piece-wise linear functions that are easy to approximate/compute, and our key/query/value matrices in the attention unit are also simple, sparse and low-rank matrices with small entries.

1.3 Related Work

In recent years, several theoretical and algorithmic aspects of transformers have been extensively studied. We discuss next two aspects that are most relevant to our work, and which we build on in the proofs of our results.

Representational strengths of Transformers.

Representational strengths of transformers have been widely studied in recent years. It has been shown that transformers have several natural limitations, including not being able to model periodic finite-state languages or hierarchical structure [35], and not being able to recognize some counter languages without large depth [12]. On the other hand, transformers are able to recognize formal languages such as Dyck languages [78], simulate finite-state automata [49] with Oâ¢(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n)italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) depth, and simulate Turing machines if given enough depth [72, 53]. There is also a line of work [34, 55] that understands what transformers can compute through the lens of circuit complexity; see [66] for a comprehensive survey.

Another line of work has shown that transformers can compute particular problems of interest, including PARITY (which perceptrons are notably unable to compute) [20] and learning problems that attention is particularly suited toward like â€œsparse averagingâ€ and â€œkğ‘˜kitalic_k-hop induction headsâ€ [64, 63].

Faster attention mechanisms.

As previously discussed, attention computation remains a bottleneck for efficiency, and many different approaches have been proposed to tackle this issue. These approaches typically result in accuracy loss (and a consequence of our main result is theoretical proof that this is necessary), which has mostly been investigated empirically.

The main prior work on theoretical limitations of subquadratic transformers weâ€™re aware of is [64]. Among other results, they study â€œkernel-based subquadratic attentionâ€ in which one heuristically computes attention faster by approximating intermediate matrices in the attention computation either by sparse matrices [45, 59, 29] or low-rank matrices [22, 48]. [64] defined a â€œkğ‘˜kitalic_k-hop induction headsâ€ task and proved that transformers can perform this task but kernel-based subquadratic attention models cannot. Our limitation result is more general than this, applying to any approach that runs in subquadratic time, rather than needing to focus on a particular architecture or heuristic.

Fine-Grained Complexity and Machine Learning

Fine-grained complexity theory has been successful at proving conditional lower bounds for problems in diverse areas of algorithm design, such as in graph theory [9, 2, 76] and combinatorial optimization [60, 8, 47, 14]. See [74] for a detailed survey.

Recently, it has been shown that many problems in machine learning are also inherently hard assuming popular conjectures in fine-grained complexity. For example, [15, 3] use ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH to give a lower bound on the time to perform kernel density estimation, [38] use ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH to demonstrate a computational phase transition in Hopfield models, and [30, 7] use ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH to give a lower bound on computational complexity of approximating the attention mechanism itself. We remark that our results, together, give a new, alternate proof of the hardness of attention assuming ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH. Indeed, we prove that a single attention unit can solve ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD}sansserif_MSD, and that ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD}sansserif_MSD requires quadratic time assuming ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH, which together imply that evaluating the attention unit requires quadratic time.

Hardness of similarity search.

Similarity search has been a fundamental area in modern machine learning, and the efficiency of similarity search algorithms has been well-studied through the lens of fine-grained complexity. Perhaps the most well-known problem in this area is the nearest neighbor problem.

Nearest Neighbor is a fundamental problem in machine learning which has been the subject of decades of research [40, 4, 6, 5, 68, 31, 69, 32]. Given a dataset PâŠ†â„dğ‘ƒsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘P\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_P âŠ† blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with nğ‘›nitalic_n points, we want to preprocess it such that given a query point qâˆˆâ„dğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘q\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_q âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, one can find its nearest neighbor in Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P (in some metric) efficiently. The nearest neighbor problem gives one common way of classifying objects in machine learning: given an object with unknown label, one just find its nearest neighbor in the dataset and use its label as the label for the target object. In addition, it has many applications in classical similarity search over different types of data including text, images, audio (see [61] for a complete overview).

There are many natural variants of the nearest neighbor problem, including the closest (furthest) pair problem where one is given a dataset Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P and wants to find the two points from Pğ‘ƒPitalic_P that are the closest (furthest). This problem is exactly ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯â¢(ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯)ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}(\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP})sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP ( sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP ) if we let inner product be the measure of closeness. Under standard Euclidean distance, one can also express the distance between two points as â€–pâˆ’qâ€–=â€–pâ€–+â€–qâ€–âˆ’2â¢âŸ¨p,qâŸ©normğ‘ğ‘normğ‘normğ‘2ğ‘ğ‘\|p-q\|=\|p\|+\|q\|-2\langle p,q\rangleâˆ¥ italic_p - italic_q âˆ¥ = âˆ¥ italic_p âˆ¥ + âˆ¥ italic_q âˆ¥ - 2 âŸ¨ italic_p , italic_q âŸ© such that when all points have the same â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}roman_â„“ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm, finding the closest pair is equivalent to finding the pair with the largest inner product, i.e. ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP. In fact, it has been shown that assuming ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH is true, finding closest pairs in Euclidean or Manhattan distance both require quadratic time [10, 60]. We will use this in our proofs below.

2 Preliminaries

Notation.

The softmax operator, when given a vector vâˆˆâ„nğ‘£superscriptâ„ğ‘›v\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_v âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, outputs a vector in â„nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT given by

softmaxâ¢(v)=(expâ¡(vâ¢[1]),â€¦,expâ¡(vâ¢[n]))âˆ‘i=1nexpâ¡(vâ¢[i]).softmaxğ‘£ğ‘£delimited-[]1â€¦ğ‘£delimited-[]ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘£delimited-[]ğ‘–\textup{softmax}(v)=\frac{(\exp(v[1]),\ldots,\exp(v[n]))}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\exp(v% [i])}.softmax ( italic_v ) = divide start_ARG ( roman_exp ( italic_v [ 1 ] ) , â€¦ , roman_exp ( italic_v [ italic_n ] ) ) end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_exp ( italic_v [ italic_i ] ) end_ARG .

For matrices Aâˆˆâ„nÃ—nğ´superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘›A\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}italic_A âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we apply softmax operator row-wise, so that

softmaxâ¢(A)i,:=softmaxâ¢(Ai,:).softmaxsubscriptğ´ğ‘–:softmaxsubscriptğ´ğ‘–:\textup{softmax}(A)_{i,:}=\textup{softmax}(A_{i,:}).softmax ( italic_A ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , : end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = softmax ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , : end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

2.1 The Transformer Architecture

Transformer is a machine learning architecture composed mainly of attention layers and multi-layer perceptrons (MLP). We model the input to a attention unit is a nÃ—dinğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘inn\times d_{\textup{in}}italic_n Ã— italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT matrix where dinsubscriptğ‘‘ind_{\textup{in}}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the input dimension and the output of a attention is a nÃ—doutğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘outn\times d_{\textup{out}}italic_n Ã— italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT out end_POSTSUBSCRIPT matrix where doutsubscriptğ‘‘outd_{\textup{out}}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT out end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the output dimension.

Definition 2.1 (attention).

For input dimension dinâˆˆâ„•subscriptğ‘‘inâ„•d_{\textup{in}}\in\mathbb{N}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_N, output dimension doutâˆˆâ„•subscriptğ‘‘outâ„•d_{\textup{out}}\in\mathbb{N}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT out end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_N, embedding dimension mâˆˆâ„•ğ‘šâ„•m\in\mathbb{N}italic_m âˆˆ blackboard_N, matrices Q,Kâˆˆâ„dinÃ—mğ‘„ğ¾superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘inğ‘šQ,K\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\textup{in}}\times m}italic_Q , italic_K âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Vâˆˆâ„dinÃ—doutğ‘‰superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘insubscriptğ‘‘outV\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\textup{in}}\times d_{\textup{out}}}italic_V âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT out end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, a attention is a mapping AQ,K,V:â„nÃ—dinâ†’â„nÃ—dout:subscriptğ´ğ‘„ğ¾ğ‘‰â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘insuperscriptâ„ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘outA_{Q,K,V}:\mathbb{R}^{n\times d_{\textup{in}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{n\times d% _{\textup{out}}}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q , italic_K , italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT out end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by

AQ,K,Vâ¢(X)=softmaxâ¢(Xâ¢Qâ¢KâŠ¤â¢XâŠ¤)â¢Xâ¢V.subscriptğ´ğ‘„ğ¾ğ‘‰ğ‘‹softmaxğ‘‹ğ‘„superscriptğ¾topsuperscriptğ‘‹topğ‘‹ğ‘‰A_{Q,K,V}(X)=\textup{softmax}(XQK^{\top}X^{\top})XV.italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q , italic_K , italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) = softmax ( italic_X italic_Q italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_X italic_V .

We use ğ’œdin,m,dout={AQ,K,V:Qâˆˆâ„dinÃ—m,Kâˆˆâ„dinÃ—m,Vâˆˆâ„dinÃ—dout}subscriptğ’œsubscriptğ‘‘inğ‘šsubscriptğ‘‘outconditional-setsubscriptğ´ğ‘„ğ¾ğ‘‰formulae-sequenceğ‘„superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘inğ‘šformulae-sequenceğ¾superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘inğ‘šğ‘‰superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘insubscriptğ‘‘out\mathcal{A}_{d_{\textup{in}},m,d_{\textup{out}}}=\{A_{Q,K,V}:Q\in\mathbb{R}^{d% _{\textup{in}}\times m},K\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\textup{in}}\times m},V\in\mathbb{R% }^{d_{\textup{in}}\times d_{\textup{out}}}\}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT out end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q , italic_K , italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_Q âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_K âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_V âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT out end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } to denote all such attentions.

An attention layer consists of many attentions in parallel. Upon receiving input Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X, each attention computes an output locally, then the results are all concatenated into a large matrix before being sent to the next layer. Our constructions in this paper will only need transformers with one layer and one single unit of attention to illustrate representational strength (transformers with more layers and heads could only be stronger), so we omit the formal definitions of attention layers.

A multi-layer perceptron (MLP) is a type of neural network that is used to learn nonlinear relationships in data. Mathematically, it is usually formulated as a neural network with different types of activation functions [13, 52, 42] or sometimes as a more specific threshold circuit [54]. Since the universal approximation theorem [39] states that any continuous function with a finite support can be approximated by a neural network with one hidden layer, [64, 63] modeled MLP as an arbitrary function Ï•:â„dâ†’â„dâ€²:italic-Ï•â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptâ„superscriptğ‘‘â€²\phi:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{d^{\prime}}italic_Ï• : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT defined on fixed-precision vectors, and we will notationally use that definition here.

Definition 2.2 (Multi-player perceptron).

A multi-layer perceptron is represented by some continuous function Ï†:â„aâ†’â„b:ğœ‘â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘\varphi:\mathbb{R}^{a}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{b}italic_Ï† : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some positive integers a,bğ‘ğ‘a,bitalic_a , italic_b. We can apply Ï†ğœ‘\varphiitalic_Ï† to a matrix row-wisely: given any matrix Xâˆˆâ„nÃ—ağ‘‹superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘X\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times a}italic_X âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Ï†â¢(X)=(Ï†â¢(X1),â€¦,Ï†â¢(Xn))âˆˆâ„nÃ—bğœ‘ğ‘‹ğœ‘subscriptğ‘‹1â€¦ğœ‘subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘›superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘\varphi(X)=(\varphi(X_{1}),\ldots,\varphi(X_{n}))\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times b}italic_Ï† ( italic_X ) = ( italic_Ï† ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , â€¦ , italic_Ï† ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_b end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

That said, in all our constructions in this paper, it will suffice to use MLPs which are simple, piecewise-linear functions that fit in all the categories discussed above, and can be easily approximated by a small neural network or any other MLP definition.

In this work, our transformer (with a single attention unit) will be defined as a composition of the first MLP, then one attention unit, then the second MLP. This is a natural model for many well-known transformer models including BERT [28], GPT-3 [16], GPT-4 [56] and is typically used in theoretical work on simple transformersÂ [58, 64, 63].

Recall in particular that we will be designing such transformers for document similarity problems. In this case, given nğ‘›nitalic_n documents D1,â€¦,Dnsubscriptğ·1â€¦subscriptğ·ğ‘›D_{1},\ldots,D_{n}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we will let their bag-of-words embeddings

(ğ–¡ğ–®ğ–¶â¢(D1),â€¦,ğ–¡ğ–®ğ–¶â¢(Dn))âŠ¤âˆˆâ„nÃ—dsuperscriptğ–¡ğ–®ğ–¶subscriptğ·1â€¦ğ–¡ğ–®ğ–¶subscriptğ·ğ‘›topsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘(\mathsf{BOW}(D_{1}),\ldots,\mathsf{BOW}(D_{n}))^{\top}\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d}( sansserif_BOW ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , â€¦ , sansserif_BOW ( italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

be the input to our transformer, and the output of the transformer will be a real number indicating the answer to our problems.

Definition 2.3.

A transformer is a mapping ğ–³ğ–¥:â„nÃ—dâ†’â„:ğ–³ğ–¥â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘â„\mathsf{TF}:\mathbb{R}^{n\times d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}sansserif_TF : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R specified by a attention unit AQ,K,Vsubscriptğ´ğ‘„ğ¾ğ‘‰A_{Q,K,V}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q , italic_K , italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and two MLPs Ï†1:â„nÃ—dâ†’â„nÃ—din,Ï†2:â„nÃ—doutâ†’â„:subscriptğœ‘1â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘insubscriptğœ‘2:â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‘outâ„\varphi_{1}:\mathbb{R}^{n\times d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{n\times d_{\textup{in% }}},\varphi_{2}:\mathbb{R}^{n\times d_{\textup{out}}}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT out end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â†’ blackboard_R. Upon an embedding matrix Eâˆˆâ„nÃ—dğ¸superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘E\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d}italic_E âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the transformer outputs Ï†2â¢(AQ,K,Vâ¢(Ï†1â¢(E)))subscriptğœ‘2subscriptğ´ğ‘„ğ¾ğ‘‰subscriptğœ‘1ğ¸\varphi_{2}(A_{Q,K,V}(\varphi_{1}(E)))italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q , italic_K , italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_E ) ) ).

To emphasize, this is a very simplified model of a transformer with a single attention unit. We say that a transformer ğ–³ğ–¥ğ–³ğ–¥\mathsf{TF}sansserif_TF solves a problem whose input is a matrix Eâˆˆâ„nÃ—dğ¸superscriptâ„ğ‘›ğ‘‘E\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times d}italic_E âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT if ğ–³ğ–¥â¢(E)ğ–³ğ–¥ğ¸\mathsf{TF}(E)sansserif_TF ( italic_E ) is the answer of the problem on instance Eğ¸Eitalic_E. For example, for decision problems like ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,d,tsubscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘¡\mathsf{MSD}_{n,d,t}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_d , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we say ğ–³ğ–¥ğ–³ğ–¥\mathsf{TF}sansserif_TF solves ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,d,tsubscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘¡\mathsf{MSD}_{n,d,t}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_d , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if for all input v1,â€¦,vnsubscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Eğ¸Eitalic_E such that Ei,:=visubscriptğ¸ğ‘–:subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–E_{i,:}=v_{i}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , : end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all iğ‘–iitalic_i, ğ–³ğ–¥â¢(E)=1ğ–³ğ–¥ğ¸1\mathsf{TF}(E)=1sansserif_TF ( italic_E ) = 1 if there exists a pair âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©â€–viâ€–â‹…â€–vjâ€–â‰¥tsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—â‹…normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘¡\frac{\langle v_{i},v_{j}\rangle}{\|v_{i}\|\cdot\|v_{j}\|}\geq tdivide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG â‰¥ italic_t and ğ–³ğ–¥â¢(E)=0ğ–³ğ–¥ğ¸0\mathsf{TF}(E)=0sansserif_TF ( italic_E ) = 0 otherwise.

2.2 Fine-Grained Complexity

We first introduce some common notions from fine-grained complexity. In fine-grained complexity, one is usually interested in whether we can improve the running time of our algorithms by a polynomial factor. For example, the ğ–®ğ–µğ–®ğ–µ\mathsf{OV}sansserif_OV problem (defined below) has a straightforward quadratic time (ignoring logarithmic factors) algorithm, and it is a major open problem to determine whether there exists a faster, Oâ¢(n1.99)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›1.99O(n^{1.99})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1.99 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time algorithm. We say that an algorithm is truly subquadratic 333Usually in fine-grained complexity, a subquadratic time algorithm means the algorithm runs in time oâ¢(n2)ğ‘œsuperscriptğ‘›2o(n^{2})italic_o ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), and a truly subquadratic time algorithm means the algorithm runs in time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for a fixed constant Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0. For example, Oâ¢(n2/logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğ‘›O(n^{2}/\log n)italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / roman_log italic_n ) is subquadratic but not truly subquadratic. By contrast, in the context of fast attention, prior machine learning literature often just calls an approach subquadratic to mean that it is truly subquadratic, or often even almost linear time. In this work, we will use the fine-grained complexity definition and refer to such approaches as truly subquadratic. if it runs in time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for some constant Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0. In this work, all our problems have quadratic time solutions, and we are interested in whether truly subquadratic time algorithms exist.

A key technique (that we will use frequently in this work) in fine-grained complexity is the fine-grained reduction, which is a way to connect the running times of different problems. If problems ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P and ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q both have quadratic time algorithms, we say that ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P reduces to ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q (sometimes we would also say ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P is easier than ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q or ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q is harder than ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P) if a truly subquadratic time algorithm for ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q implies a truly subquadratic time algorithm for ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P. We say ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P and ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q are subquadratic equivalent if they reduce to each other, i.e. there is a truly subquadratic time algorithm for ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P}caligraphic_P if and only if there is a truly subquadratic time algorithm for ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathcal{Q}caligraphic_Q. Such relationships are proved by careful reductions, and we will see many examples soon.

2.2.1 Hardness Conjectures: ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH and ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢\mathsf{OVC}sansserif_OVC

We restate our central hardness conjecture here.

Definition 2.4 (Strong Exponential Time Hypothesis (ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH)).

For any Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0, there exists a positive integer kğ‘˜kitalic_k such that kâ¢ğ–²ğ– ğ–³ğ‘˜ğ–²ğ– ğ–³k\mathsf{SAT}italic_k sansserif_SAT requires Î©â¢(2(1âˆ’Îµ)â¢n)Î©superscript21ğœ€ğ‘›\Omega(2^{(1-\varepsilon)n})roman_Î© ( 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_Îµ ) italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time.

ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH has been one of the biggest open problem in fine-grained complexity, and one of the reasons is that ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH being true would imply ğ–¯â‰ ğ–­ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ–­ğ–¯\mathsf{P}\neq\mathsf{NP}sansserif_P â‰  sansserif_NP. See SectionÂ 1.2 for a detailed explanation of its significance and why many people believe that it is true.

We also introduce the Orthogonal Vectors problem, which is an important problem in fine-grained complexity and will be a key intermediate problem in some of our proofs.

Definition 2.5 (Orthogonal Vectors (ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT)).

Given binary vectors v1,â€¦,vnâˆˆ{0,1}â„“subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›superscript01â„“v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT asks to determine if there exists a pair iâ‰ jğ‘–ğ‘—i\neq jitalic_i â‰  italic_j such that âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©=0subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—0\langle v_{i},v_{j}\rangle=0âŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© = 0.

Usually researchers focus on the regime when â„“â‰ªnmuch-less-thanâ„“ğ‘›\ell\ll nroman_â„“ â‰ª italic_n, and thus we will assume that â„“â‰¤noâ¢(1)â„“superscriptğ‘›ğ‘œ1\ell\leq n^{o(1)}roman_â„“ â‰¤ italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_o ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT throughout this paper. The straightforward algorithm for ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT runs in time Oâ¢(n2â¢â„“)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2â„“O(n^{2}\ell)italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ ) by simply computing the inner products between each pair of vectors. In very low dimensions, one can employ a folklore recursive approach to obtain a Oâ¢(2â„“+n)ğ‘‚superscript2â„“ğ‘›O(2^{\ell}+n)italic_O ( 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_n ) time algorithm (seeÂ [24]). When â„“=câ¢logâ¡nâ„“ğ‘ğ‘›\ell=c\log nroman_â„“ = italic_c roman_log italic_n for a large constant cğ‘citalic_c, all algorithms mentioned above require quadratic time with respect to nğ‘›nitalic_n, but [11, 25] gave a slight improvement, showing that for a fixed constant c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0, ğ–®ğ–µn,câ¢logâ¡nsubscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘›\mathsf{OV}_{n,c\log n}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_c roman_log italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be solved in time n2âˆ’1/Oâ¢(logâ¡c)superscriptğ‘›21ğ‘‚ğ‘n^{2-1/O(\log c)}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - 1 / italic_O ( roman_log italic_c ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This is a truly subquadratic running time for any fixed constant cğ‘citalic_c, but becomes quadratic as cğ‘citalic_c grows. It is still unknown whether there exists a Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time algorithm for all constant cğ‘citalic_c, where Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ is an absolute constant that does not depend on cğ‘citalic_c, and the popular ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢\mathsf{OVC}sansserif_OVC Conjecture states that no such algorithm exists.

Conjecture 2.6 (ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢\mathsf{OVC}sansserif_OVC).

For any Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0, there exists a constant c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0 such that ğ–®ğ–µn,câ¢logâ¡nsubscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘›\mathsf{OV}_{n,c\log n}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_c roman_log italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot be solved in Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time.

[73] showed that assuming ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH is true, then ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢\mathsf{OVC}sansserif_OVC is true (the other direction is unknown). Our paper will use these two conjectures interchangeably such that our hardness results can be obtained from either conjecture.

There is also a bichromatic version of ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where one is given two sets of vectors A={a1,â€¦,an},B={b1,â€¦,bn}formulae-sequenceğ´subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğµsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›A=\{a_{1},\ldots,a_{n}\},B=\{b_{1},\ldots,b_{n}\}italic_A = { italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } , italic_B = { italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } such that ai,bjâˆˆ{0,1}â„“subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—superscript01â„“a_{i},b_{j}\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and wants to determine if there exists i,jğ‘–ğ‘—i,jitalic_i , italic_j such that âŸ¨ai,bjâŸ©=0subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—0\langle a_{i},b_{j}\rangle=0âŸ¨ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© = 0. In fact, these two problems are subquadratic equivalent.

Lemma 2.7.

There exists an algorithm for ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that runs in time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ‹…polyâ¡(â„“))ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€polyâ„“O(n^{2-\varepsilon}\cdot\operatorname{poly}(\ell))italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) ) for some Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0 if and only if there exists an algorithm for bichromatic ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that runs in time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ€²â‹…polyâ¡(â„“))ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘›2superscriptğœ€â€²polyâ„“O(n^{2-\varepsilon^{\prime}}\cdot\operatorname{poly}(\ell))italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) ) for some Îµâ€²>0superscriptğœ€â€²0\varepsilon^{\prime}>0italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0.

Proof.

First we assume that there exists an algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A for bichromatic ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that runs in time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ‹…polyâ¡(â„“))ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€polyâ„“O(n^{2-\varepsilon}\cdot\operatorname{poly}(\ell))italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) ) for some Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0. Given an ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT instance V={v1,â€¦,vn}ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›V=\{v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\}italic_V = { italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } with viâˆˆ{0,1}â„“subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–superscript01â„“v_{i}\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all iğ‘–iitalic_i, we first check if any visubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–v_{i}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the all zero vector (if so then it is a yes instance). Otherwise, let A=B=Vğ´ğµğ‘‰A=B=Vitalic_A = italic_B = italic_V and run ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A on A,Bğ´ğµA,Bitalic_A , italic_B. Notice that since there is no all zero vector, âŸ¨vi,viâŸ©â‰ 0subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–0\langle v_{i},v_{i}\rangle\neq 0âŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© â‰  0 for all iğ‘–iitalic_i, and therefore there exists iâ‰ jğ‘–ğ‘—i\neq jitalic_i â‰  italic_j such that âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©=0subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—0\langle v_{i},v_{j}\rangle=0âŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© = 0 if and only if there exists vi=aâˆˆA,vj=bâˆˆBformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘ğ´subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘ğµv_{i}=a\in A,v_{j}=b\in Bitalic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_a âˆˆ italic_A , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_b âˆˆ italic_B such that âŸ¨a,bâŸ©=0ğ‘ğ‘0\langle a,b\rangle=0âŸ¨ italic_a , italic_b âŸ© = 0. The total running time is Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ‹…polyâ¡(â„“)+nâ¢â„“)=Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ‹…polyâ¡(â„“))ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€polyâ„“ğ‘›â„“ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€polyâ„“O(n^{2-\varepsilon}\cdot\operatorname{poly}(\ell)+n\ell)=O(n^{2-\varepsilon}% \cdot\operatorname{poly}(\ell))italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) + italic_n roman_â„“ ) = italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) ).

Now we assume that there exists an algorithm ğ’œâ€²superscriptğ’œâ€²\mathcal{A}^{\prime}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that runs in time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ‹…polyâ¡(â„“))ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€polyâ„“O(n^{2-\varepsilon}\cdot\operatorname{poly}(\ell))italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) ) for some Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0. Let A={a1,â€¦,an},B={b1,â€¦,bn}formulae-sequenceğ´subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğµsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›A=\{a_{1},\ldots,a_{n}\},B=\{b_{1},\ldots,b_{n}\}italic_A = { italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } , italic_B = { italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } with vectors ai,bjâˆˆ{0,1}â„“subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—superscript01â„“a_{i},b_{j}\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a bichromatic ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT instance.
