Notice that now âŸ¨aiâ€²,ajâ€²âŸ©,âŸ¨biâ€²,bjâ€²âŸ©â‰¥1superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—â€²1\langle a_{i}^{\prime},a_{j}^{\prime}\rangle,\langle b_{i}^{\prime},b_{j}^{% \prime}\rangle\geq 1âŸ¨ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© , âŸ¨ italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© â‰¥ 1 for all i,jğ‘–ğ‘—i,jitalic_i , italic_j. As a result, if there exists âŸ¨ai,bjâŸ©=0subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—0\langle a_{i},b_{j}\rangle=0âŸ¨ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© = 0, then âŸ¨aiâ€²,bjâ€²âŸ©=âŸ¨ai,bjâŸ©+0=0superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—â€²subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—00\langle a_{i}^{\prime},b_{j}^{\prime}\rangle=\langle a_{i},b_{j}\rangle+0=0âŸ¨ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© = âŸ¨ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© + 0 = 0. Conversely, if âŸ¨v,wâŸ©=0ğ‘£ğ‘¤0\langle v,w\rangle=0âŸ¨ italic_v , italic_w âŸ© = 0 for any v,wâˆˆAâ€²âˆªBâ€²ğ‘£ğ‘¤superscriptğ´â€²superscriptğµâ€²v,w\in A^{\prime}\cup B^{\prime}italic_v , italic_w âˆˆ italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆª italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then it must be the case that v=aiâ€²ğ‘£superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–â€²v=a_{i}^{\prime}italic_v = italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and w=bjâ€²ğ‘¤superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—â€²w=b_{j}^{\prime}italic_w = italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some i,jğ‘–ğ‘—i,jitalic_i , italic_j or vice versa, which implies that âŸ¨ai,bjâŸ©=0subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—0\langle a_{i},b_{j}\rangle=0âŸ¨ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© = 0. Therefore, running ğ’œâ€²superscriptğ’œâ€²\mathcal{A}^{\prime}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT on Aâ€²âˆªBâ€²superscriptğ´â€²superscriptğµâ€²A^{\prime}\cup B^{\prime}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆª italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT will tell us whether A,Bğ´ğµA,Bitalic_A , italic_B is a yes instance or not. The total running time required is Oâ¢((2â¢n)2âˆ’Îµâ‹…polyâ¡(â„“+2))=Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ¢polyâ¡(â„“))ğ‘‚â‹…superscript2ğ‘›2ğœ€polyâ„“2ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€polyâ„“O((2n)^{2-\varepsilon}\cdot\operatorname{poly}(\ell+2))=O(n^{2-\varepsilon}% \operatorname{poly}(\ell))italic_O ( ( 2 italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ + 2 ) ) = italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) ). âˆ

When â„“=câ¢logâ¡nâ„“ğ‘ğ‘›\ell=c\log nroman_â„“ = italic_c roman_log italic_n for some constant c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0, an algorithm running in Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ‹…polyâ¡(â„“))ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€polyâ„“O(n^{2-\varepsilon}\cdot\operatorname{poly}(\ell))italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) ) time for some fixed constant Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0 is a truly subquadratic algorithm. Therefore, Lemma 2.7 implies that assuming ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢\mathsf{OVC}sansserif_OVC, there is no truly subquadratic algorithm for bichromatic ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

2.2.2 Minimum Inner Product

In this section we introduce the minimum inner product problem, an important problem related to similarity search.

Definition 2.8 (ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP).

Given a set of binary vectors v1,â€¦,vnâˆˆ{0,1}â„“subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›superscript01â„“v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT asks to find one pair of 1â‰¤i,jâ‰¤n,iâ‰ jformulae-sequence1ğ‘–formulae-sequenceğ‘—ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘—1\leq i,j\leq n,i\neq j1 â‰¤ italic_i , italic_j â‰¤ italic_n , italic_i â‰  italic_j such that âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—\langle v_{i},v_{j}\rangleâŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© is minimum.

The trivial algorithm for ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT takes Oâ¢(n2â¢â„“)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2â„“O(n^{2}\ell)italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ ) time by enumerating all possible pairs of inner product. Sometimes we are happy with finding a pair of vectors whose inner product is close enough to optimal, so we also introduce the approximate ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP problem as follows.

Definition 2.9 (Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ›¾-ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-ğ–¨ğ–¯\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}italic_Î³ - sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP).

Given a set of binary vectors v1,â€¦,vnâˆˆ{0,1}â„“subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›superscript01â„“v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ›¾-ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT asks to find one pair of 1â‰¤i,jâ‰¤n,iâ‰ jformulae-sequence1ğ‘–formulae-sequenceğ‘—ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘—1\leq i,j\leq n,i\neq j1 â‰¤ italic_i , italic_j â‰¤ italic_n , italic_i â‰  italic_j such that âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—\langle v_{i},v_{j}\rangleâŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© is a Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³-approximation of the minimal inner product.

It is not hard to see that ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP and Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ›¾-ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-ğ–¨ğ–¯\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}italic_Î³ - sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP are both at least as hard as ğ–®ğ–µğ–®ğ–µ\mathsf{OV}sansserif_OV for any Î³â‰¥1ğ›¾1\gamma\geq 1italic_Î³ â‰¥ 1 (just find the minimum inner product and see if it is 00, and any multiplicative approximation of 00 must be 00). Therefore, assuming ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢\mathsf{OVC}sansserif_OVC, for any Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0 there exists c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0 such that ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,câ¢logâ¡nğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘›\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,c\log n}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_c roman_log italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot be solved in Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time.

In addition, there is a decision version of ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP, by which we denote ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“,tğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where one wants to know whether there exists a pair of vectors whose inner product is at most tğ‘¡titalic_t for some 0â‰¤tâ‰¤â„“0ğ‘¡â„“0\leq t\leq\ell0 â‰¤ italic_t â‰¤ roman_â„“.

Definition 2.10 (ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP decision version).

Given a set of binary vectors v1,â€¦,vnâˆˆ{0,1}â„“subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›superscript01â„“v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 0â‰¤tâ‰¤â„“0ğ‘¡â„“0\leq t\leq\ell0 â‰¤ italic_t â‰¤ roman_â„“, ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“,tğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT asks to determine if there exists one pair of 1â‰¤i,jâ‰¤n,iâ‰ jformulae-sequence1ğ‘–formulae-sequenceğ‘—ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘—1\leq i,j\leq n,i\neq j1 â‰¤ italic_i , italic_j â‰¤ italic_n , italic_i â‰  italic_j such that âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©â‰¤tsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘¡\langle v_{i},v_{j}\rangle\leq tâŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© â‰¤ italic_t.

ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is trivially at least as hard as ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“,tğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any tğ‘¡titalic_t because if we can calculate the minimum, then we can decide whether it is at most tğ‘¡titalic_t or not. In addition, notice that when tâ‰¥â„“+1ğ‘¡â„“1t\geq\ell+1italic_t â‰¥ roman_â„“ + 1 or t<0ğ‘¡0t<0italic_t < 0 the problem is trivial and requires constant time to respond.

The bichromatic versions of these problems can be defined analogously: given two sets A,Bğ´ğµA,Bitalic_A , italic_B with vectors in {0,1}â„“superscript01â„“\{0,1\}^{\ell}{ 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, one needs to find i,jğ‘–ğ‘—i,jitalic_i , italic_j that achieves (for bichromatic ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) or approximates (for bichromatic Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ›¾-ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) the minimal âŸ¨ai,bjâŸ©subscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘—\langle a_{i},b_{j}\rangleâŸ¨ italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ©. One can easily obtain a truly subquadratic algorithm for all three problems above given a truly subquadratic algorithm for their bichromatic versions.

Lemma 2.11.

Suppose there exists an algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A for bichromatic ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that runs in time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ‹…polyâ¡(â„“))ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€polyâ„“O(n^{2-\varepsilon}\cdot\operatorname{poly}(\ell))italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) ) for any Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0, then there exists an algorithm for ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that runs in time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ€²â‹…polyâ¡(â„“))ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘›2superscriptğœ€â€²polyâ„“O(n^{2-\varepsilon^{\prime}}\cdot\operatorname{poly}(\ell))italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) ) for some Îµâ€²>0superscriptğœ€â€²0\varepsilon^{\prime}>0italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0. The same statement is true for Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ›¾-ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“,tğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proof.

Given a ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT instance V={v1,â€¦,vn}ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›V=\{v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\}italic_V = { italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, we first partition Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V into V1,V2subscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2V_{1},V_{2}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of equal size and run ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A on V1,V2subscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2V_{1},V_{2}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This will allow us to find the minimal pair in V1Ã—V2subscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰2V_{1}\times V_{2}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Now we further partition V1subscriptğ‘‰1V_{1}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into two sets of equal size and recurse on V1subscriptğ‘‰1V_{1}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to eventually find the minimal pair in V1Ã—V1subscriptğ‘‰1subscriptğ‘‰1V_{1}\times V_{1}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Similarly we recurse on V2subscriptğ‘‰2V_{2}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to find the minimal pair in V2Ã—V2subscriptğ‘‰2subscriptğ‘‰2V_{2}\times V_{2}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The running time of our algorithm is

polyâ¡(â„“)â‹…âˆ‘i=1logâ¡nOâ¢((n2i)(2âˆ’Îµ))=Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ‹…polyâ¡(â„“)â‹…logâ¡n)â‰¤Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ€²â‹…polyâ¡(â„“))â‹…polyâ„“superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›superscript2ğ‘–2ğœ€ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€polyâ„“ğ‘›ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘›2superscriptğœ€â€²polyâ„“\operatorname{poly}(\ell)\cdot\sum_{i=1}^{\log n}O\Big{(}\Big{(}\frac{n}{2^{i}% }\Big{)}^{(2-\varepsilon)}\Big{)}=O(n^{2-\varepsilon}\cdot\operatorname{poly}(% \ell)\cdot\log n)\leq O(n^{2-\varepsilon^{\prime}}\cdot\operatorname{poly}(% \ell))roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) â‹… âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( ( divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 - italic_Îµ ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) â‹… roman_log italic_n ) â‰¤ italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) )

for some Îµâ€²>0superscriptğœ€â€²0\varepsilon^{\prime}>0italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0. The exact same argument holds for Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ›¾-ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as well because the minimal pair must appear in some recursion where we run our algorithm on. The argument also holds for ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“,tğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT because we have gone over all possible pairs of vectors. âˆ

2.2.3 Maximum Inner Product

In this section we introduce the maximum inner product problem and its variants. The problems are basically the same as problems in the previous section.

Definition 2.12 (ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP).

Given a set of binary vectors v1,â€¦,vnâˆˆ{0,1}â„“subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›superscript01â„“v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT asks to find one pair of 1â‰¤i,jâ‰¤n,iâ‰ jformulae-sequence1ğ‘–formulae-sequenceğ‘—ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘—1\leq i,j\leq n,i\neq j1 â‰¤ italic_i , italic_j â‰¤ italic_n , italic_i â‰  italic_j such that âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—\langle v_{i},v_{j}\rangleâŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© is maximal.

Definition 2.13 (Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ›¾-ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-ğ–¨ğ–¯\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}italic_Î³ - sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP).

Given a set of binary vectors v1,â€¦,vnâˆˆ{0,1}â„“subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›superscript01â„“v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ›¾-ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT asks to find one pair of 1â‰¤i,jâ‰¤n,iâ‰ jformulae-sequence1ğ‘–formulae-sequenceğ‘—ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘—1\leq i,j\leq n,i\neq j1 â‰¤ italic_i , italic_j â‰¤ italic_n , italic_i â‰  italic_j such that âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—\langle v_{i},v_{j}\rangleâŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© is a Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³-approximation of the maximal inner product.

Definition 2.14 (ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP decision version).

Given a set of binary vectors v1,â€¦,vnâˆˆ{0,1}â„“subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›superscript01â„“v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“,tğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT asks to determine if there exists one pair of 1â‰¤i,jâ‰¤n,iâ‰ jformulae-sequence1ğ‘–formulae-sequenceğ‘—ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘—1\leq i,j\leq n,i\neq j1 â‰¤ italic_i , italic_j â‰¤ italic_n , italic_i â‰  italic_j such that âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©â‰¥tsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘¡\langle v_{i},v_{j}\rangle\geq tâŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© â‰¥ italic_t.

The bichromatic versions of these problems can be defined analogously. Similar to ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP, one can easily obtain a truly subquadratic algorithm for all three problems above given a truly subquadratic algorithm for their bichromatic versions again using the proof of Lemma 2.11.

Lemma 2.15.

Suppose there exists an algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A for bichromatic (Î³â¢-)â¢ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ›¾-ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“(\gamma\text{-})\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}( italic_Î³ - ) sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that runs in time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ‹…polyâ¡(â„“))ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€polyâ„“O(n^{2-\varepsilon}\cdot\operatorname{poly}(\ell))italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) ) for any Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0, then there exists an algorithm for (Î³â¢-)â¢ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ›¾-ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“(\gamma\text{-})\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}( italic_Î³ - ) sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that runs in time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ€²â‹…polyâ¡(â„“))ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘›2superscriptğœ€â€²polyâ„“O(n^{2-\varepsilon^{\prime}}\cdot\operatorname{poly}(\ell))italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) ) for some Îµâ€²>0superscriptğœ€â€²0\varepsilon^{\prime}>0italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0.

It is less obvious whether ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP is a harder problem than ğ–®ğ–µğ–®ğ–µ\mathsf{OV}sansserif_OV or not. The answer is positive, and for bichromatic ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP, there exists a simple proof.

Lemma 2.16.

Suppose there exists an algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A for bichromatic ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that runs in time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ‹…polyâ¡(â„“))ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€polyâ„“O(n^{2-\varepsilon}\cdot\operatorname{poly}(\ell))italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) ) for any Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0, then there exists an algorithm for ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that runs in time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ‹…polyâ¡(â„“))ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€polyâ„“O(n^{2-\varepsilon}\cdot\operatorname{poly}(\ell))italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) ).

Proof.

Given an ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT instance v1,â€¦,vnâˆˆ{0,1}â„“subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›superscript01â„“v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we partition all visubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–v_{i}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into subsets S1,â€¦,Sâ„“subscriptğ‘†1â€¦subscriptğ‘†â„“S_{1},\ldots,S_{\ell}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that each Sjsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘—S_{j}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT contains all vectors with jğ‘—jitalic_j ones. Now for each pair of 1â‰¤i,jâ‰¤â„“formulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—â„“1\leq i,j\leq\ell1 â‰¤ italic_i , italic_j â‰¤ roman_â„“, let SÂ¯jsubscriptÂ¯ğ‘†ğ‘—\bar{S}_{j}overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT consists of vectors in Sjsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘—S_{j}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT but with all the entries flipped. As a result, for any vâˆˆSi,wâˆˆSÂ¯jformulae-sequenceğ‘£subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘¤subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†ğ‘—v\in S_{i},w\in\bar{S}_{j}italic_v âˆˆ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w âˆˆ overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we have âŸ¨v,wâŸ©=iâˆ’âŸ¨v,wÂ¯âŸ©ğ‘£ğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘£Â¯ğ‘¤\langle v,w\rangle=i-\langle v,\bar{w}\rangleâŸ¨ italic_v , italic_w âŸ© = italic_i - âŸ¨ italic_v , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG âŸ©, which implies that âŸ¨v,wÂ¯âŸ©=0ğ‘£Â¯ğ‘¤0\langle v,\bar{w}\rangle=0âŸ¨ italic_v , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_w end_ARG âŸ© = 0 if and only if âŸ¨v,wâŸ©=iğ‘£ğ‘¤ğ‘–\langle v,w\rangle=iâŸ¨ italic_v , italic_w âŸ© = italic_i. Therefore, running ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A on Si,SÂ¯jsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–subscriptÂ¯ğ‘†ğ‘—S_{i},\bar{S}_{j}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , overÂ¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT will tell us whether there is an orthogonal pair of vectors in Sisubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–S_{i}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Sjsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘—S_{j}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The total running time is Oâ¢(â„“2â‹…n2âˆ’Îµâ‹…polyâ¡(â„“))=Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)â‹…polyâ¡(â„“)ğ‘‚â‹…superscriptâ„“2superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€polyâ„“â‹…ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€polyâ„“O(\ell^{2}\cdot n^{2-\varepsilon}\cdot\operatorname{poly}(\ell))=O(n^{2-% \varepsilon})\cdot\operatorname{poly}(\ell)italic_O ( roman_â„“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ) ) = italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) â‹… roman_poly ( roman_â„“ ). âˆ

In fact, [46] proved a stronger statement which says that even approximate ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is stronger than ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for some approximation factor.

2.3 Document Similarity Problems

In this section we formally define the ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£,ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD},\mathsf{LSD}sansserif_MSD , sansserif_LSD problems that we will study. First we define the ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD}sansserif_MSD variants, which are defined similarly to ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP variants.

Definition 2.17 (ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD}sansserif_MSD).

Given nğ‘›nitalic_n document embeddings v1,â€¦,vnâˆˆ{0,1}â„“subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›superscript01â„“v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT asks to find 1â‰¤i,jâ‰¤n,iâ‰ jformulae-sequence1ğ‘–formulae-sequenceğ‘—ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘—1\leq i,j\leq n,i\neq j1 â‰¤ italic_i , italic_j â‰¤ italic_n , italic_i â‰  italic_j such that âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©â€–viâ€–â‹…â€–vjâ€–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—â‹…normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—\frac{\langle v_{i},v_{j}\rangle}{\|v_{i}\|\cdot\|v_{j}\|}divide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG is the maximum. 444In all versions of ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD}sansserif_MSD and ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{LSD}sansserif_LSD, we assume that there are no zero vectors.

Even though ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD}sansserif_MSD looks similar to ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP, notice that they are not the same problem because of normalization. For example, v=(1,1,â€¦,1)âˆˆâ„â„“ğ‘£11â€¦1superscriptâ„â„“v=(1,1,\ldots,1)\in\mathbb{R}^{\ell}italic_v = ( 1 , 1 , â€¦ , 1 ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and w=(1,1,â€¦,1,0,â€¦,0)âˆˆâ„â„“ğ‘¤11â€¦10â€¦0superscriptâ„â„“w=(1,1,\ldots,1,0,\ldots,0)\in\mathbb{R}^{\ell}italic_w = ( 1 , 1 , â€¦ , 1 , 0 , â€¦ , 0 ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where wğ‘¤witalic_w has â„“/2â„“2\ell/2roman_â„“ / 2 ones have a very large inner product but they might not be considered similar. In contrast, vâ€²=(1,1,â€¦,1,0,â€¦,0)âˆˆâ„â„“superscriptğ‘£â€²11â€¦10â€¦0superscriptâ„â„“v^{\prime}=(1,1,\ldots,1,0,\ldots,0)\in\mathbb{R}^{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( 1 , 1 , â€¦ , 1 , 0 , â€¦ , 0 ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where vâ€²superscriptğ‘£â€²v^{\prime}italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has 10101010 ones and wâ€²=(0,1,â€¦,1,0,â€¦,0)âˆˆâ„â„“superscriptğ‘¤â€²01â€¦10â€¦0superscriptâ„â„“w^{\prime}=(0,1,\ldots,1,0,\ldots,0)\in\mathbb{R}^{\ell}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( 0 , 1 , â€¦ , 1 , 0 , â€¦ , 0 ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where wâ€²superscriptğ‘¤â€²w^{\prime}italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has 10101010 ones have a inner product of 9999 but they are very similar in terms of cosine similarity.

Definition 2.18 (Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ›¾-ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{MSD}italic_Î³ - sansserif_MSD).

Given nğ‘›nitalic_n document embeddings v1,â€¦,vnâˆˆ{0,1}â„“subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›superscript01â„“v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“ğ›¾-subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT asks to find 1â‰¤iâˆ—,jâˆ—â‰¤n,iâˆ—â‰ jâˆ—formulae-sequence1superscriptğ‘–formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘—ğ‘›superscriptğ‘–superscriptğ‘—1\leq i^{*},j^{*}\leq n,i^{*}\neq j^{*}1 â‰¤ italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_n , italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that

Definition 2.19 (ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD}sansserif_MSD decision version).

Given nğ‘›nitalic_n document embeddings v1,â€¦,vnâˆˆ{0,1}â„“subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›superscript01â„“v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“,tsubscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT asks to determine if there exists 1â‰¤i,jâ‰¤n,iâ‰ jformulae-sequence1ğ‘–formulae-sequenceğ‘—ğ‘›ğ‘–ğ‘—1\leq i,j\leq n,i\neq j1 â‰¤ italic_i , italic_j â‰¤ italic_n , italic_i â‰  italic_j such that âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©â€–viâ€–â‹…â€–vjâ€–â‰¥tsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—â‹…normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘¡\frac{\langle v_{i},v_{j}\rangle}{\|v_{i}\|\cdot\|v_{j}\|}\geq tdivide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG â‰¥ italic_t.

It is not hard to see that Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“ğ›¾-subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“,tsubscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are both easier than ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD}sansserif_MSD. In addition, notice that the number of possible tğ‘¡titalic_t can be considered as discrete because there could only be Oâ¢(â„“3)ğ‘‚superscriptâ„“3O(\ell^{3})italic_O ( roman_â„“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) possible values of âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©â€–viâ€–â‹…â€–vjâ€–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—â‹…normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—\frac{\langle v_{i},v_{j}\rangle}{\|v_{i}\|\cdot\|v_{j}\|}divide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG. As a result, the existence of truly subquadratic time algorithm for ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“,tsubscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all tâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¡01t\in[0,1]italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] would imply a truly subquadratic time algorithm for ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using binary search.

Bichromatic versions of these problems can be defined analogously and the proof of Lemma 2.11 again tells us that bichromatic versions are harder.

We also formally define ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{LSD}sansserif_LSD variants, which are defined similarly to ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP variants.

Definition 2.21 (Î³â¢-â¢ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ›¾-ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{LSD}italic_Î³ - sansserif_LSD).

min1â‰¤i,jâ‰¤nâ¡âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©â€–viâ€–â‹…â€–vjâ€–â‰¤âŸ¨viâˆ—,vjâˆ—âŸ©â€–viâˆ—â€–â‹…â€–vjâˆ—â€–â‰¤Î³â‹…min1â‰¤i,jâ‰¤nâ¡âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©â€–viâ€–â‹…â€–vjâ€–.subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘›subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—â‹…normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—subscriptğ‘£superscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘£superscriptğ‘—â‹…normsubscriptğ‘£superscriptğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘£superscriptğ‘—â‹…ğ›¾subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘›subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—â‹…normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—\min_{1\leq Î³â¢-â¢ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“ğ›¾-subscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“,tsubscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are both easier than ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{LSD}sansserif_LSD. In addition, the existence of truly subquadratic time algorithm for ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“,tsubscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all tğ‘¡titalic_t again implies a truly subquadratic time algorithm for ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“subscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell}sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using binary search. Bichromatic versions of these problems can be defined analogously and the proof of Lemma 2.11 again tells us that bichromatic versions are harder.

3 Hardness of Document Similarity

In this section, we show that assuming ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH or ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢\mathsf{OVC}sansserif_OVC, for any Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0, there exists a constant c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0 (only depends on Îµğœ€\varepsilonitalic_Îµ) such that many variants of ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,câ¢logâ¡n,ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,câ¢logâ¡nsubscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘›\mathsf{LSD}_{n,c\log n},\mathsf{MSD}_{n,c\log n}sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_c roman_log italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_c roman_log italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT require Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time.

Theorem 3.1.

Assuming ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH or ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢\mathsf{OVC}sansserif_OVC, for every Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0, there exists a constant c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0 such that Î³â¢-â¢ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“ğ›¾-subscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot be solved in Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time for any Î³â‰¥1ğ›¾1\gamma\geq 1italic_Î³ â‰¥ 1 when â„“=câ¢logâ¡nâ„“ğ‘ğ‘›\ell=c\log nroman_â„“ = italic_c roman_log italic_n.

Proof.

Assume by contradiction that there exists an algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A for Î³â¢-â¢ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,câ¢logâ¡nğ›¾-subscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘›\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{LSD}_{n,c\log n}italic_Î³ - sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_c roman_log italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that runs in time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for some Î³â‰¥1,Îµ>0formulae-sequenceğ›¾1ğœ€0\gamma\geq 1,\varepsilon>0italic_Î³ â‰¥ 1 , italic_Îµ > 0 and any constant c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0. We show that ğ–®ğ–µn,câ¢logâ¡nsubscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘›\mathsf{OV}_{n,c\log n}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_c roman_log italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be solved in time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for any constant c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0, which refutes ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢\mathsf{OVC}sansserif_OVC and ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH.

Otherwise we run ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A on v1,â€¦,vnsubscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to compute iâˆ—,jâˆ—superscriptğ‘–superscriptğ‘—i^{*},j^{*}italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that

min1â‰¤i,jâ‰¤nâ¡âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©â€–viâ€–â‹…â€–vjâ€–â‰¤âŸ¨viâˆ—,vjâˆ—âŸ©â€–viâˆ—â€–â‹…â€–vjâˆ—â€–â‰¤Î³â‹…min1â‰¤i,jâ‰¤nâ¡âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©â€–viâ€–â‹…â€–vjâ€–.subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘›subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—â‹…normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—subscriptğ‘£superscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘£superscriptğ‘—â‹…normsubscriptğ‘£superscriptğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘£superscriptğ‘—â‹…ğ›¾subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘›subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—â‹…normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—\min_{1\leq Observe that min1â‰¤i,jâ‰¤nâ¡âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©â€–viâ€–â‹…â€–vjâ€–=0subscriptformulae-sequence1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘›subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—â‹…normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—0\displaystyle\min_{1\leq i,j\leq n}\frac{\langle v_{i},v_{j}\rangle}{\|v_{i}\|% \cdot\|v_{j}\|}=0roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 â‰¤ italic_i , italic_j â‰¤ italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG = 0 if and only if there exists a pair of orthogonal vectors, which implies that there exists a pair of orthogonal vectors if and only if ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A outputs a pair of orthogonal vectors. The total amount of time needed for ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is therefore Oâ¢(nâ¢â„“+n2âˆ’Îµ)=Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚ğ‘›â„“superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n\ell+n^{2-\varepsilon})=O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n roman_â„“ + italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), which refutes ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH. âˆ

Since Î³â¢-â¢ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“ğ›¾-subscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is easier than ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“subscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell}sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and bichromatic Î³â¢-â¢ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“ğ›¾-subscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the same lower bound applies to these two problems as well. In addition, there must exist tâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¡01t\in[0,1]italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] such that ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“,tsubscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot be solved in Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time when â„“=câ¢logâ¡nâ„“ğ‘ğ‘›\ell=c\log nroman_â„“ = italic_c roman_log italic_n because otherwise that would imply a Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time algorithm for ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“subscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell}sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using binary search.

Corollary 3.2.

Assuming ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH or ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢\mathsf{OVC}sansserif_OVC, for every Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0, there exists a constant c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0 such that ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,dsubscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›ğ‘‘\mathsf{LSD}_{n,d}sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot be solved in Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time when â„“â‰¥câ¢logâ¡nâ„“ğ‘ğ‘›\ell\geq c\log nroman_â„“ â‰¥ italic_c roman_log italic_n. Moreover, the same lower bound holds for bichromatic Î³â¢-â¢ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“ğ›¾-subscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\gamma\textup{-}\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all Î³â‰¥1ğ›¾1\gamma\geq 1italic_Î³ â‰¥ 1 and ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“,tsubscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for some tâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¡01t\in[0,1]italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ].

A similar hardness result for Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,dğ›¾-subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›ğ‘‘\gamma\textup{-}\mathsf{MSD}_{n,d}italic_Î³ - sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be derived with much more complicated techniques. Our proof follows the same idea as Theorem 6.1 of [46] which uses graph constructions, and we delay the proof of TheoremÂ 3.3 to AppendixÂ A.

Theorem 3.3.

Assuming ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH, for every Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0, there exists a constant c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0 such that Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“ğ›¾-subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\gamma\textup{-}\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot be solved in Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time when

â„“â‰¥(logâ¡n)câ¢logâ¡n(logâ¡logâ¡n)2â¢Â andÂ â¢Î³â‰¤(1+1logâ¡logâ¡n)logâ¡n(logâ¡logâ¡n)2.â„“superscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›2Â andÂ ğ›¾superscript11ğ‘›ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›2\ell\geq(\log n)^{\frac{c\log n}{(\log\log n)^{2}}}\textup{ and }\gamma\leq% \Big{(}1+\frac{1}{\log\log n}\Big{)}^{\frac{\log n}{(\log\log n)^{2}}}.roman_â„“ â‰¥ ( roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_c roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG ( roman_log roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and italic_Î³ â‰¤ ( 1 + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG ( roman_log roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Similarly, the hardness result also applies to harder problems including ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and bichromatic Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“ğ›¾-subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\gamma\textup{-}\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Corollary 3.4.

Assuming ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH or ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢\mathsf{OVC}sansserif_OVC, for every Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0, there exists a constant c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0 such that ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot be solved in Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time when â„“â‰¥(logâ¡n)câ¢logâ¡n(logâ¡logâ¡n)2â„“superscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›2\ell\geq(\log n)^{\frac{c\log n}{(\log\log n)^{2}}}roman_â„“ â‰¥ ( roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_c roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG ( roman_log roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Moreover, the same lower bound holds for bichromatic Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“ğ›¾-subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\gamma\textup{-}\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all 1â‰¤Î³â‰¤(1+1logâ¡logâ¡n)logâ¡n(logâ¡logâ¡n)21ğ›¾superscript11ğ‘›ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›21\leq\gamma\leq(1+\frac{1}{\log\log n})^{\frac{\log n}{(\log\log n)^{2}}}1 â‰¤ italic_Î³ â‰¤ ( 1 + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG ( roman_log roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“,tsubscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for some tâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¡01t\in[0,1]italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ].

4 Representational Strength of Transformers

So far we have seen multiple problems (ğ–®ğ–µ,ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯,ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–®ğ–µğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{OV},\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP},\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_OV , sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP , sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP and variants of ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£,ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD},\mathsf{LSD}sansserif_MSD , sansserif_LSD) that require quadratic time to solve under certain parameters assuming ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH or ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢\mathsf{OVC}sansserif_OVC. In this section, we show that ğ–®ğ–µğ–®ğ–µ\mathsf{OV}sansserif_OV and decision versions of ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£,ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD},\mathsf{LSD}sansserif_MSD , sansserif_LSD can be solved by a transformer with one attention unit.

Notice that fine-grained reduction does not trivially apply in representational strength of transformers, i.e. two problems might be subquadratic equivalent, but one problem solvable by transformers might not imply that the other one is also solvable by transformers. This is because many techniques that are simple to do on the word-RAM model (where one can do arithmetic operations, find the maximum/minimum over nğ‘›nitalic_n numbers in constant time) might not be easy to implement in parallel architectures like transformers.

To start with, we show that transformers are able to solve ğ–®ğ–µğ–®ğ–µ\mathsf{OV}sansserif_OV with appropriate parameters.

Theorem 4.1.

A attention unit with input and output MLPs with parameters d=â„“,din=â„“,dout=1,mâ‰¥â„“+1formulae-sequenceğ‘‘â„“formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‘inâ„“formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‘out1ğ‘šâ„“1d=\ell,d_{\textup{in}}=\ell,d_{\textup{out}}=1,m\geq\ell+1italic_d = roman_â„“ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_â„“ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT out end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 , italic_m â‰¥ roman_â„“ + 1 can solve ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proof.

Let v1,â€¦,vnâˆˆ{0,1}â„“subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›superscript01â„“v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be an ğ–®ğ–µn,â„“subscriptğ–®ğ–µğ‘›â„“\mathsf{OV}_{n,\ell}sansserif_OV start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT instance; define vn+1:=0â„“assignsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘›1superscript0â„“v_{n+1}:=0^{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := 0 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Xâˆˆâ„(n+1)Ã—â„“ğ‘‹superscriptâ„ğ‘›1â„“X\in\mathbb{R}^{(n+1)\times\ell}italic_X âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n + 1 ) Ã— roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that Xi,:=visubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–:subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–X_{i,:}=v_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , : end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all iğ‘–iitalic_i. Since mâ‰¥â„“+1ğ‘šâ„“1m\geq\ell+1italic_m â‰¥ roman_â„“ + 1, let Q,Kğ‘„ğ¾Q,Kitalic_Q , italic_K be arbitrary matrices such that Qâ¢KâŠ¤=âˆ’3â¢logâ¡nâ‹…Iâ„“ğ‘„superscriptğ¾top3â‹…ğ‘›subscriptğ¼â„“QK^{\top}=-3\log n\cdot I_{\ell}italic_Q italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = - 3 roman_log italic_n â‹… italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Vâˆˆâ„â„“Ã—1ğ‘‰superscriptâ„â„“1V\in\mathbb{R}^{\ell\times 1}italic_V âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ Ã— 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the all-one matrix. Let AQ,K,Vsubscriptğ´ğ‘„ğ¾ğ‘‰A_{Q,K,V}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q , italic_K , italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote this attention head, and Ï†1subscriptğœ‘1\varphi_{1}italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the identity function.

Let Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X be the input to the transformer with AQ,K,Vsubscriptğ´ğ‘„ğ¾ğ‘‰A_{Q,K,V}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q , italic_K , italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the only attention head. We claim that if there exists a pair 1â‰¤iâ‰ jâ‰¤n1ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘›1\leq i\neq j\leq n1 â‰¤ italic_i â‰  italic_j â‰¤ italic_n such that âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©=0subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—0\langle v_{i},v_{j}\rangle=0âŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© = 0, then AQ,K,Vâ¢(X)subscriptğ´ğ‘„ğ¾ğ‘‰ğ‘‹A_{Q,K,V}(X)italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q , italic_K , italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) has an entry which is at least 1n+11ğ‘›1\frac{1}{n+1}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n + 1 end_ARG, and otherwise all entries will be at most 1(n+1)1.51superscriptğ‘›11.5\frac{1}{(n+1)^{1.5}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_n + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1.5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG. As a result, we can use the second MLP Ï†2subscriptğœ‘2\varphi_{2}italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to map AQ,K,Vâ¢(X)subscriptğ´ğ‘„ğ¾ğ‘‰ğ‘‹A_{Q,K,V}(X)italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q , italic_K , italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_X ) to 1111 if any of its entry is at least 1n+11ğ‘›1\frac{1}{n+1}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_n + 1 end_ARG and 00 otherwise (see Lemma B.1 for a formal proof of existence).

âˆ

Now we show that transformers can solve ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP and ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP.

Theorem 4.2.

A attention unit with input and output MLPs with parameters d=â„“,din=â„“+1,dout=1,mâ‰¥â„“+1formulae-sequenceğ‘‘â„“formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‘inâ„“1formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‘out1ğ‘šâ„“1d=\ell,d_{\textup{in}}=\ell+1,d_{\textup{out}}=1,m\geq\ell+1italic_d = roman_â„“ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_â„“ + 1 , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT out end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 , italic_m â‰¥ roman_â„“ + 1 can solve ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“,tğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“,tğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for 1â‰¤tâ‰¤â„“1ğ‘¡â„“1\leq t\leq\ell1 â‰¤ italic_t â‰¤ roman_â„“.

Proof.

Given a ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT instance v1,â€¦,vnâˆˆ{0,1}â„“subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›superscript01â„“v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\in\{0,1\}^{\ell}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Vâˆˆâ„nÃ—â„“ğ‘‰superscriptâ„ğ‘›â„“V\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times\ell}italic_V âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n Ã— roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that Vi,:=visubscriptğ‘‰ğ‘–:subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–V_{i,:}=v_{i}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , : end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all iğ‘–iitalic_i, let xi=(vi,1)âˆˆ{0,1}â„“+1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘–1superscript01â„“1x_{i}=(v_{i},1)\in\{0,1\}^{\ell+1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 ) âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for all iğ‘–iitalic_i, xn+1:=(0,â€¦,0,t+1)âˆˆâ„â„“+1assignsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›10â€¦0ğ‘¡1superscriptâ„â„“1x_{n+1}:=(0,\ldots,0,t+1)\in\mathbb{R}^{\ell+1}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := ( 0 , â€¦ , 0 , italic_t + 1 ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Xâˆˆâ„(n+1)Ã—(â„“+1)ğ‘‹superscriptâ„ğ‘›1â„“1X\in\mathbb{R}^{(n+1)\times(\ell+1)}italic_X âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_n + 1 ) Ã— ( roman_â„“ + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be such that Xi,:=xisubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–:subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–X_{i,:}=x_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , : end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all iğ‘–iitalic_i. Let Q,Kâˆˆâ„dinÃ—mğ‘„ğ¾superscriptâ„subscriptğ‘‘inğ‘šQ,K\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{\textup{in}}\times m}italic_Q , italic_K âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT Ã— italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be such that Qâ¢KâŠ¤=3â¢logâ¡nâ‹…Idinğ‘„superscriptğ¾top3â‹…ğ‘›subscriptğ¼subscriptğ‘‘inQK^{\top}=3\log n\cdot I_{d_{\textup{in}}}italic_Q italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ¤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 3 roman_log italic_n â‹… italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, V=(1,1,â€¦,1,0)âˆˆâ„â„“+1ğ‘‰11â€¦10superscriptâ„â„“1V=(1,1,\ldots,1,0)\in\mathbb{R}^{\ell+1}italic_V = ( 1 , 1 , â€¦ , 1 , 0 ) âˆˆ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and AQ,K,Vsubscriptğ´ğ‘„ğ¾ğ‘‰A_{Q,K,V}italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Q , italic_K , italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote this attention head.

We want to send Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X to the attention head, which could be done by many ways given the input Vğ‘‰Vitalic_V. âˆ‘j=1nexpâ¡(3â¢logâ¡nâ‹…âŸ¨xi,xjâŸ©)âˆ‘k=1nexpâ¡(3â¢logâ¡nâ‹…âŸ¨xi,xkâŸ©)+expâ¡(3â¢(t+1)â¢logâ¡n)â‹…â€–vjâ€–1=âˆ‘j=1nn3â¢âŸ¨xi,xjâŸ©â‹…â€–vjâ€–1âˆ‘k=1nn3â¢âŸ¨xi,xkâŸ©+n3â¢(t+1).superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘›â‹…â‹…3ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›â‹…3ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜3ğ‘¡1ğ‘›subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—1superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘›â‹…superscriptğ‘›3subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›3subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘›3ğ‘¡1\sum_{j=1}^{n}\frac{\exp(3\log Let 1â‰¤iâˆ—â‰ jâˆ—â‰¤n1superscriptğ‘–superscriptğ‘—ğ‘›1\leq i^{*}\neq j^{*}\leq n1 â‰¤ italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰  italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_n be such that âŸ¨viâˆ—,vjâˆ—âŸ©subscriptğ‘£superscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘£superscriptğ‘—\langle v_{i^{*}},v_{j^{*}}\rangleâŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© is the largest. âˆ‘j=1nnâˆ’3â¢âŸ¨xiâˆ—,xjâŸ©â‹…â€–vjâ€–1âˆ‘k=1nnâˆ’3â¢âŸ¨xiâˆ—,xkâŸ©+nâˆ’3â¢(t+1)â‰¤â„“â‹…nâ‹…nâˆ’3â¢(t+2)nâˆ’3â¢(t+1)=â„“n2<1(n+1)1.5.superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘›â‹…superscriptğ‘›3subscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—1superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›3subscriptğ‘¥superscriptğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜superscriptğ‘›3ğ‘¡1â‹…â„“â‹…ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›3ğ‘¡2superscriptğ‘›3ğ‘¡1â„“superscriptğ‘›21superscriptğ‘›11.5\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{n}n^{-3\langle x_{i^{*}},x_{j}\rangle}\cdot\|v_{j}\|_{1}}{% \sum_{k=1}^{n}n^{-3\langle x_{i^{*}},x_{k}\rangle}+n^{-3(t+1)}}\leq\ell\cdot% \frac{n\cdot n^{-3(t+2)}}{n^{-3(t+1)}}=\frac{\ell}{n^{2}}<\frac{1}{(n+1)^{1.5}}.divide start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 âŸ¨ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â‹… âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‘ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 âŸ¨ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ— end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG â‰¤ roman_â„“ â‹… divide start_ARG italic_n â‹… italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 ( italic_t + 2 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 ( italic_t + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG ( italic_n + 1 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1.5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG .

âˆ

Finally, we show that transformers can solve decision versions of document similarity problems.

Theorem 4.3.

A attention unit with input and output MLPs with parameters d=â„“,din=â„“+1,dout=1,mâ‰¥â„“+1formulae-sequenceğ‘‘â„“formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‘inâ„“1formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘‘out1ğ‘šâ„“1d=\ell,d_{\textup{in}}=\ell+1,d_{\textup{out}}=1,m\geq\ell+1italic_d = roman_â„“ , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT in end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_â„“ + 1 , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT out end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 , italic_m â‰¥ roman_â„“ + 1 can solve ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“,tsubscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“,tsubscriptğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“ğ‘¡\mathsf{LSD}_{n,\ell,t}sansserif_LSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any tâˆˆ[0,1]ğ‘¡01t\in[0,1]italic_t âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ].

Proof.

When t=0ğ‘¡0t=0italic_t = 0 the problem is trivial so we simply need to output 1111 using MLPs, so without losing of generality we assume tâ‰ 0ğ‘¡0t\neq 0italic_t â‰  0. Since ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD}sansserif_MSD is exactly ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP after we normalize the document embeddings, the proof of TheoremÂ 4.2 implies that it suffices to send Xğ‘‹Xitalic_X to the attention head. See Lemma B.3 for a construction.

The proof for ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£ğ–«ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{LSD}sansserif_LSD is exactly the same as the proof for ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¬ğ—‚ğ—‡-ğ–¨ğ–¯\mathsf{Min}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}sansserif_Min - sansserif_IP after applying the Ï†1subscriptğœ‘1\varphi_{1}italic_Ï† start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT construced in Lemma B.3. âˆ

  • YPPN [21] Shunyu Yao, Binghui Peng, ChristosÂ H. Papadimitriou, and Karthik Narasimhan. Self-attention networks can process bounded hierarchical languages. In Chengqing Zong, Fei Xia, Wenjie Li, and Roberto Navigli, editors, Proceedings of the 59th Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics and the 11th International Joint Conference on Natural Language Processing, ACL/IJCNLP 2021, (Volume 1: Long Papers), Virtual Event, August 1-6, 2021, pages 3770â€“3785. Association for Computational Linguistics, 2021.
  • ZHDK [23] Amir Zandieh, Insu Han, Majid Daliri, and Amin Karbasi. Kdeformer: accelerating transformers via kernel density estimation. In Proceedings of the 40th International Conference on Machine Learning, ICMLâ€™23. JMLR.org, 2023.

Appendix A Proof of TheoremÂ 3.3

In this section we prove TheoremÂ 3.3. Recall the theorem as follows.

Theorem A.1 (TheoremÂ 3.3).

Assuming ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§ğ–²ğ–¤ğ–³ğ–§\mathsf{SETH}sansserif_SETH or ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢ğ–®ğ–µğ–¢\mathsf{OVC}sansserif_OVC and Î³â‰¤(1+1logâ¡logâ¡n)logâ¡n(logâ¡logâ¡n)2=2(logâ¡n)1âˆ’oâ¢(1)ğ›¾superscript11ğ‘›ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›2superscript2superscriptğ‘›1ğ‘œ1\gamma\leq(1+\frac{1}{\log\log n})^{\frac{\log n}{(\log\log n)^{2}}}=2^{(\log n% )^{1-o(1)}}italic_Î³ â‰¤ ( 1 + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG ( roman_log roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 - italic_o ( 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, for every Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0 there exists a constant c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0 such that there is no algorithm for Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“ğ›¾-subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that runs in time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) where â„“=(logâ¡n)câ¢logâ¡n(logâ¡logâ¡n)2â„“superscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›2\ell=(\log n)^{\frac{c\log n}{(\log\log n)^{2}}}roman_â„“ = ( roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_c roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG ( roman_log roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

We break down the proof into several lemmas below.

Lemma A.2.

Suppose there exists an algorithm for Î³â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“ğ›¾-subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\gamma\text{-}\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell}italic_Î³ - sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where â„“=(logâ¡n)câ¢logâ¡n(logâ¡logâ¡n)2â„“superscriptğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›2\ell=(\log n)^{\frac{c\log n}{(\log\log n)^{2}}}roman_â„“ = ( roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_c roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG ( roman_log roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for any constant c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0, Î³â‰¤(1+1logâ¡logâ¡n)logâ¡n(logâ¡logâ¡n)2ğ›¾superscript11ğ‘›ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›2\gamma\leq(1+\frac{1}{\log\log n})^{\frac{\log n}{(\log\log n)^{2}}}italic_Î³ â‰¤ ( 1 + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG ( roman_log roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that runs in Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time for any Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0, then there exists an algorithm for (1+1logâ¡logâ¡n)â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,(logâ¡n)k11ğ‘›-subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜(1+\frac{1}{\log\log n})\text{-}\mathsf{MSD}_{n,(\log n)^{k}}( 1 + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG ) - sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , ( roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with running time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for any constant k>0ğ‘˜0k>0italic_k > 0.

Proof.

Let v1,â€¦,vnâˆˆ{0,1}(logâ¡n)ksubscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›superscript01superscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\in\{0,1\}^{(\log n)^{k}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆˆ { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be an instance of (1+1logâ¡logâ¡n)â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,(logâ¡n)k11ğ‘›-subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜(1+\frac{1}{\log\log n})\text{-}\mathsf{MSD}_{n,(\log n)^{k}}( 1 + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG ) - sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , ( roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any constant k>0ğ‘˜0k>0italic_k > 0. Notice that we have

âŸ¨viâŠ—q,vjâŠ—qâŸ©â€–viâŠ—qâ€–â‹…â€–vjâŠ—qâ€–=(âŸ¨vi,vjâŸ©â€–viâ€–â‹…â€–vjâ€–)qsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–tensor-productabsentğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—tensor-productabsentğ‘â‹…normsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–tensor-productabsentğ‘normsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—tensor-productabsentğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘£ğ‘—â‹…normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘—ğ‘\frac{\langle v_{i}^{\otimes q},v_{j}^{\otimes q}\rangle}{\|v_{i}^{\otimes q}% \|\cdot\|v_{j}^{\otimes q}\|}=\Big{(}\frac{\langle v_{i},v_{j}\rangle}{\|v_{i}% \|\cdot\|v_{j}\|}\Big{)}^{q}divide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ— italic_q end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ— italic_q end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ— italic_q end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âŠ— italic_q end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG = ( divide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT âˆ¥ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

for any i,jğ‘–ğ‘—i,jitalic_i , italic_j, so an Î³ğ›¾\gammaitalic_Î³-approximation of ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD}sansserif_MSD on Vâ€²superscriptğ‘‰â€²V^{\prime}italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a Î³1/q=(1+1logâ¡logâ¡n)superscriptğ›¾1ğ‘11ğ‘›\gamma^{1/q}=(1+\frac{1}{\log\log n})italic_Î³ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / italic_q end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( 1 + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG ) approximation of ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£\mathsf{MSD}sansserif_MSD on v1,â€¦,vnsubscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. âˆ

Now we define the bichromatic Î³â¢-Additive-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ›¾-Additive-ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£\gamma\text{-Additive-}\mathsf{MSD}italic_Î³ -Additive- sansserif_MSD problem as: given a A,BâŠ†{0,1}â„“,Î±âˆˆ[0,1]formulae-sequenceğ´ğµsuperscript01â„“ğ›¼01A,B\subseteq\{0,1\}^{\ell},\alpha\in[0,1]italic_A , italic_B âŠ† { 0 , 1 } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_â„“ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_Î± âˆˆ [ 0 , 1 ] with |A|=|B|=nğ´ğµğ‘›|A|=|B|=n| italic_A | = | italic_B | = italic_n, we want to distinguish between the following two cases:

  1. 1.

    Yes instance: There exists (a,b)âˆˆAÃ—Bğ‘ğ‘ğ´ğµ(a,b)\in A\times B( italic_a , italic_b ) âˆˆ italic_A Ã— italic_B such that âŸ¨a,bâŸ©â€–aâ€–â‹…â€–bâ€–â‰¥Î±ğ‘ğ‘â‹…normğ‘normğ‘ğ›¼\frac{\langle a,b\rangle}{\|a\|\cdot\|b\|}\geq\alphadivide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_a , italic_b âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_a âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ italic_b âˆ¥ end_ARG â‰¥ italic_Î±.

    No instance: For every (a,b)âˆˆAÃ—Bğ‘ğ‘ğ´ğµ(a,b)\in A\times B( italic_a , italic_b ) âˆˆ italic_A Ã— italic_B we have âŸ¨a,bâŸ©â€–aâ€–â‹…â€–bâ€–<Î±âˆ’Î³ğ‘ğ‘â‹…normğ‘normğ‘ğ›¼ğ›¾\frac{\langle a,b\rangle}{\|a\|\cdot\|b\|}<\alpha-\gammadivide start_ARG âŸ¨ italic_a , italic_b âŸ© end_ARG start_ARG âˆ¥ italic_a âˆ¥ â‹… âˆ¥ italic_b âˆ¥ end_ARG < italic_Î± - italic_Î³.

Lemma A.3.

Suppose there exists an algorithm ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A for (1+1logâ¡logâ¡n)â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,(logâ¡n)k11ğ‘›-subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜(1+\frac{1}{\log\log n})\text{-}\mathsf{MSD}_{n,(\log n)^{k}}( 1 + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG ) - sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , ( roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any constant k>0ğ‘˜0k>0italic_k > 0 with Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) running time, then there exists an algorithm for bichromatic logâ¡nâ„“â¢-Additive-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,câ¢logâ¡nğ‘›â„“-Additive-subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘›\frac{\log n}{\ell}\textup{-Additive-}\mathsf{MSD}_{n,c\log n}divide start_ARG roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG -Additive- sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_c roman_log italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0 in time Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ€²)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2superscriptğœ€â€²O(n^{2-\varepsilon^{\prime}})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) for some Îµâ€²>0superscriptğœ€â€²0\varepsilon^{\prime}>0italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0.

Proof.

The proof follows from TheoremÂ A.4 and LemmaÂ A.5 below, where TheoremÂ A.4 shows that the lemma statement is true if we replace logâ¡nâ„“â¢-Additive-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,câ¢logâ¡nğ‘›â„“-Additive-subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘›\frac{\log n}{\ell}\textup{-Additive-}\mathsf{MSD}_{n,c\log n}divide start_ARG roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG -Additive- sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_c roman_log italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by (logâ¡n)â¢-Additive-â¢ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,câ¢logâ¡nğ‘›-Additive-ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘›(\log n)\textup{-Additive-}\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,c\log n}( roman_log italic_n ) -Additive- sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_c roman_log italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and LemmaÂ A.5 shows that these two problems are subquadratic equivalent. âˆ

Theorem A.4 ([46] Theorem 6.2).

Suppose there exists an algorithm for (1+1logâ¡logâ¡n)â¢-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,(logâ¡n)k11ğ‘›-subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›superscriptğ‘›ğ‘˜(1+\frac{1}{\log\log n})\textup{-}\mathsf{MSD}_{n,(\log n)^{k}}( 1 + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_n end_ARG ) - sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , ( roman_log italic_n ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any constant k>0ğ‘˜0k>0italic_k > 0 that runs in Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµ)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2ğœ€O(n^{2-\varepsilon})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time for any Îµ>0ğœ€0\varepsilon>0italic_Îµ > 0, then there exists an algorithm for bichromatic (logâ¡n)â¢-Additive-â¢ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,câ¢logâ¡nğ‘›-Additive-ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›ğ‘ğ‘›(\log n)\textup{-Additive-}\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,c\log n}( roman_log italic_n ) -Additive- sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , italic_c roman_log italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for any constant c>0ğ‘0c>0italic_c > 0 that runs in Oâ¢(n2âˆ’Îµâ€²)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2superscriptğœ€â€²O(n^{2-\varepsilon^{\prime}})italic_O ( italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time for some Îµâ€²>0superscriptğœ€â€²0\varepsilon^{\prime}>0italic_Îµ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > 0.

Lemma A.5.

Bichromatic logâ¡nâ„“â¢-Additive-â¢ğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£n,â„“ğ‘›â„“-Additive-subscriptğ–¬ğ–²ğ–£ğ‘›â„“\frac{\log n}{\ell}\textup{-Additive-}\mathsf{MSD}_{n,\ell}divide start_ARG roman_log italic_n end_ARG start_ARG roman_â„“ end_ARG -Additive- sansserif_MSD start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with â„“=Oâ¢(logâ¡n)â„“ğ‘‚ğ‘›\ell=O(\log n)roman_â„“ = italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) and bichromatic (logâ¡n)â¢-Additive-â¢ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“â€²ğ‘›-Additive-ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›superscriptâ„“â€²(\log n)\textup{-Additive-}\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell^{\prime}}( roman_log italic_n ) -Additive- sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with â„“â€²=Oâ¢(logâ¡n)superscriptâ„“â€²ğ‘‚ğ‘›\ell^{\prime}=O(\log n)roman_â„“ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_O ( roman_log italic_n ) are subquadratic equivalent.

Proof.

Given a bichromatic (logâ¡n)â¢-Additive-â¢ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘â¢-â¢ğ–¨ğ–¯n,â„“ğ‘›-Additive-ğ–¬ğ–ºğ—‘-subscriptğ–¨ğ–¯ğ‘›â„“(\log n)\textup{-Additive-}\mathsf{Max}\text{-}\mathsf{IP}_{n,\ell}( roman_log italic_n ) -Additive- sansserif_Max - sansserif_IP start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n , roman_â„“ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT instance with sets A={a1,â€¦,an},B={b1,â€¦,bn}formulae-sequenceğ´subscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğµsubscriptğ‘1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›A=\{a_{1},\ldots,a_{n}\},B=\{b_{1},\ldots,b_{n}\}italic_A = { italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } , italic_B = { italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and integer Î±ğ›¼\alphaitalic_Î±, we construct Aâ€²={a1â€²,â€¦,anâ€²},Bâ€²={b1â€²,â€¦,bnâ€²}formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ´â€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘1â€²â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›â€²superscriptğµâ€²superscriptsubscriptğ‘1â€²â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›â€²A^{\prime}=\{a_{1}^{\prime},\ldots,a_{n}^{\prime}\},B^{\prime}=\{b_{1}^{\prime% },\ldots,b_{n}^{\prime}\}italic_A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } , italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT â€² end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } as follows: for each aisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–a_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we first attach â„“âˆ’â€–aiâ€–1â„“subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘ğ‘–1\ell-\|a_{i}\|_{1}roman_â„“ -
